context: Wonderful now what?
It always turns out just like it does in the movies.

"Performing tasks that will help people live more fulfilling lives at work and at home."

Oh my!  Mankind is in deep trouble, no mark that, DEEP TROUBLE, if we thin a robot will lead to fulfilment living life.  Fulfillment is not found in robots, or other such nonsense.  While robots may be useful, there is no way to connect the dots between robots and fulfillment.  Fulfillment hinges of an understanding of meaning and purpose.  Sadly, many people today have no clue about meaning and purpose.  

Prof Marston of New York University recently did a survey.  He asked 3,000 people, “What have you to live for?"  94% were enduring the present, hoping for something in the future. They had no substance on what they were hoping for.  

With 94% only enduring, meaning and purpose, (hence fulfillment) was beyond their reach.  No robot will make the 94%, 50%, or 25%.  When we search the wrong places, we cannot expect to find answers.

replies.context:
Robots like this will enhance the lives of millions of people that are too old to do some things and others that are handicapped.
Someday they will be able to cook, clean help lift someone who may have fallen, call for help when someone is in trouble.
You remember the commercials of the woman on the ground that yells "I've fallen and can't get up" you remember how you laughed? A properly designed robot could help her get up or call for help and guard her from harm until help arrives.
What a bout a chair that a paralyzed person can sit in and it will walk outside and around the neighborhood, walk up a set of stairs with the person sitting in it, the store etc.
You don't think this will be fulfillment in the purist form? 
You sound like a technophobe to me.

Not any of your examples apply to a "fulfilled" life.  You missed the entire paragraph about the 94% - absolutely nothing to do with the woman on the floor, paralyzed person.  

No technophobe here - been involved with technology for more than  50 years.  I had a long career based in technology.  What was done with this bi-ped is amazing and well intentioned.  But, adding fulfillment, ... no, not at all.   Some of the least fulfilled people I know are deep into technology.  Recall my comment about looking in the wrong places....?

Remember, when the personal computer began an upswing, mid-80s?  Consider what Ken Olson said regarding PCs. The goal was to make things easier so that people would have "more time to do what they wanted to do."  Remember when cell phones first came to the market, "... make life easier."  How many people are slaves to this technology in 2021?  What happened to all the relief of time, "to do what you want to do?"
